awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Hydrodynamic and Muscular Mechanical Investigation of Maneuverability in Cephalopods throughout Ontogeny
awd_abstract_narration:
Squids and cuttlefishes are impressive swimmers, having the ability to hover, change direction rapidly, and even swim forward and backward with ease.  The key to their locomotive prowess is coordination among their pulsed jet, flapping fins, and flexible arms, but little is presently known about how these units work together throughout these animals' lives as they encounter different physical environments, change developmentally, and experience dissimilar ecosystems. This project focuses on understanding how the jet, fins, and arms operate in concert to produce the necessary forces for exceptional turning, both in terms of muscle capabilities and hydrodynamics, in squid and cuttlefish of different developmental stages (hatchlings to adults).  This work will involve cutting edge 3D flow visualization approaches, high-speed video analysis, and advanced mathematical tools that highlight the essential components of high-performance turns.  This project promises to (1) advance our understanding of how highly maneuverable marine animals navigate through their complex habitats and (2) reveal key performance characteristics, structures, and behaviors that can be integrated potentially into the design of mechanical bio-inspired systems, such as autonomous underwater vehicles, to improve their turning/docking capabilities.  This project incorporates a number of outreach projects, including demonstrations in local schools, participation in robotics competitions, development of web-based tutorials and summer camps, and presentations at aquariums and museums. 

Maneuvering in the aquatic environment is a significant component of routine swimming, with proficient maneuvering being essential for predator avoidance, prey capture, and navigation.  Despite its importance, understanding of the biomechanics of maneuvering behaviors is limited.  An investigation of maneuvering performance in three morphologically distinct species of cephalopods is proposed here.  The investigation explores three broad questions: (1) how are the fins, arms, and funnel-jet complex used in concert to maximize turning performance in adult cephalopods; (2) do the relative importance of turning rate and turning radius change over ontogeny and are fewer turning modes observed in young cephalopods; and (3) do fin, arm, and funnel musculoskeletal mechanics change over ontogeny and are such changes associated with differences in maneuvering? These questions will be addressed by collecting measurements of 3D high-speed kinematics and 2D/3D hydrodynamics of wake flows; performing mathematical analyses to quantitatively identify and categorize turning patterns; and measuring both the dynamic passive and active length-force relationship and maximum shortening velocity of muscle fibers that drive the movements used during turning and jet vectoring.  The proposed work will: (1) provide data on how an ecologically important marine animal coordinates its novel dual-mode system (jet and fins) and arms to achieve high turning performance, (2) highlight the essential kinematic and hydrodynamic elements of turns, (3) offer insights into how maneuvering capabilities change over a broad ontogenetic range, and (4) provide novel data on the muscle properties of muscular hydrostatic organs and their role in turning.

por.por_cntn:
Squids and cuttlefishes are impressive swimmers, having the ability to hover, change direction rapidly, and even swim forward and backward with ease. For these animals and other oceanic swimmers, proficient maneuvering is essential for predator avoidance, prey capture, navigation, and even mating. Despite its ecological importance, little is known about the turning performance of squids and cuttlefishes, which are central to food web dynamics in the world's oceans. Using 2D/3D flow quantification approaches, high-speed video analysis, and musculoskeletal system measurements, three broad questions were explored in three squids (brief squid, longfin squid, shortfin squid) and two cuttlefishes (European common cuttlefish, dwarf cuttlefish): (1) how are the fins, arms, and funnel-jet complex used in concert to maximize turning performance in adult cephalopods; (2) do the relative importance of turning rate and turning radius change with age and are fewer turning modes observed in young cephalopods; and (3) do fin, arm, and funnel musculoskeletal mechanics change over ontogeny and are such changes associated with differences in maneuvering?

 

Results from the project indicated that the jet was the primary driver of turns, producing a range of flows from simple, short, directed pulses to complex, extended, powerful pulses, depending on the type of maneuver. While the jet was integral for turning, no one jet property predicted performance across the squids and cuttlefishes, with jet length-to-diameter ratio, velocity, and frequency all playing roles. Turning orientation (forward vs backward) was important for performance; forward turns were generally associated with shorter jet pulses and tighter rotations, whereas backward turns were most often associated with longer jets and faster rotations. Although the fins and arms played a subordinate role in turns relative to the jet, they were important in augmenting forces to effect or slow turns, providing stabilization, counteracting negative buoyancy (squids), and reducing inertial/hydrodynamic resistance. In general, the shallowest water squid (brief squid) exhibited greater turning performance than larger, deeper-water cephalopods. Younger squids and cuttlefishes turned more broadly but faster than adults, with some larval squid reaching angular velocities >7,500 deg s-1, which are faster than those reported for any other aquatic animal. At early developmental stages, squid turned more proficiently than cuttlefish, both in terms of turning radius and angular velocity. As all cephalopods advanced to older life stages, they relied increasingly on their fins for turning and exhibited greater flexibility in jet flow dynamics, although two primary jet modes (short pulses and long pulses) remained in their turning toolkit throughout their lives. Morphological examination of the fin, arms, and funnel did not reveal dramatic changes in the musculoskeletal system that may drive the ontogenetic differences in fin kinematics and turning dynamics. One exception, however, was that the volume fraction of collagenous connective tissue fibers that provide structural support and that also limit amplitudes of movement in the fin, arms, and funnel increased significantly during growth in squids and cuttlefishes. Another difference was that the muscle fibers of the hatchlings had relatively smaller cross-sectional areas of myofilaments (i.e., the parts of a muscle cell that actively produce force) than adults. Both of these ontogenetic differences suggest that the fins, arms, and funnels of young animals are less stiff and more deformable, but weaker, than those of adults.

 

The project provided training for both undergraduates (27) and graduate students (7), including 22 women, 8 first-generation students, and 5 from groups underrepresented in the sciences. Results from this study were disseminated through scientific journal publications, national and international conferences, public tours, and science exhibits. The PIs also worked closely with educational outreach outlets, including a mentoring young scientists program aimed at getting students excited about careers in marine science, a marine-themed summer camp that introduced students to squid and other local marine fauna, and a high school science and technology festival. Furthermore, project data enhanced our understanding of the mechanisms underlying maneuverability in a diverse group of animals with a unique dual mode propulsive system (jet and fins) and explored methods for characterizing the diversity of their maneuvers, with potential downstream applications for highly maneuverable bioinspired underwater vehicles.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2022
Modified by: Joseph T Thompson
